bibliography.head: Books from Grantland Rice's Library in J.U.L. Collection:
A. Monographs written or edited by Grantland Rice:

4. Sportlights of 1923 / By / Grantland Rice / G. P. Putnam's Sons / New York & London / The Knickerbocker Press / 192*f. vii + 212 p.
5. Songs of the Open ¿_ By Grantland Rice / The Century Co. / New York & London /192V. ix + 227 p.
6. Rice, Grantland, and Harford Powel, eds. The Omnibus of Sport-/ illustrated by Lee Townsend / Harper 8c Brothers Publishers / New York and London /1932/. xvii + 809 p.

blockquote.p: Signed on fly-leaf: "Grantland Rice / 22 W. 48th St. / N.Y.C."

bibliography.bibref: 8. Henderson, Daniel, John Kieran, and Grantland Rice, eds. Reveille / War Poems by Members of Our Armed Forces / Selected by / Daniel Henderson / John Kie_ran / Grantland Rice / A. S. Barnes and Company / New York /194¿/* xviii + "&t p.

bibliography.bibref: 1. Adams, Franklin P. In Other Words. Garden City New York / Doubleday, Page & Company / 1912. x + 151 p. "To the Rices--Kate, Grant and Floncey with some affection, some affection being right. From Frank. October 29, 1912."

Ed Anthony"

blockquote.p: "Dedicated To: A really big man who took the time, To encourage my youthful attempts to rhyme.
(printed dedication) This volume was born of the friendly advice, of the man who inspired it -- Grantland Rice!"

"5/8/43 To Grantland Rice - a man I have never seen but who nevertheless is responsible for anything worthwhile that this volume may contain. But for his encouragement (and reassurance), 22 years ago, I would never have been able to continue writing in the face of the apathy, indifference, and ridicule I encountered from everyone else. It is fitting that the book be dedicated to the man who made it possible, and when I return from the South Pacific (I leave in 4 days), it is my fondest hope to meet the man, personally, to v/hom the book is dedicated, -- Grantland Rice! / Wayne B. Stone, Lt. U.S.N.R.

"(Officially this book cannot be released until approved by the Navy Dept. However, in view of my recent orders to join the third amphibious Force (at my request as psychiatrist), I could not resist sending you a copy, and asking you to keep it "under cover," until you hear from me that the Navy,Dept. has approved it for distribution to service men (via the Red Cross), -- or that I am again a civilian (after the Pacific war is over), and can release it myself. W.B.S."
